authors: Doris Schroeder, Kate Chatfield, Michelle Singh

components.content:
Have you heard about the TRUST Code, a Global Code of Conduct for Equitable Research Partnerships?
(The code was previously known as the Global Code of Conduct for Research in Resource-Poor Settings.)
components.feedback: For those of you who are familiar with the TRUST Code, this is a refresher. For the newcomers, welcome on board! We hope you will find the code useful.

components.title: Ethics Dumping Exercise
components.subtitle: Complete this exercise by finding which example corresponds to each ethics dumping type.
components.description:
Each bucket can contain exactly one item. It might require a short waiting time before you can drag the next item.
If you wish to change your choices, you can easily do this by clicking on the 'undo' icon that appears on each item when selected.
components.feedback: Thank you. Your feedback has been submitted.

bucket_items.label: Avoiding ethics approval knowing that local ethics oversight is weakened through lack of resources.
Monetizing samples abroad without benefit sharing in the location where the samples were taken.
Working with a rural indigenous community in a low income setting without seeking community approval.
Not undertaking any risk assessments in an area where involvement in research can lead to high incrimination or stigmatization risks for research participants.
Making promises about employing local research assistants, which are not kept when the research starts.
Defining the research problem and developing the research plan for a setting where one has no local collaborators or local insights.

components.content: Click on the three values you personally prioritize in your work as a researcher (anonymous poll) and see what others have done.

components.prompt: Please tick only your top answer in this anonymous poll. Who can best ensure that international research partnerships are equitable?

options.title: Research funders have the most power to ensure research is undertaken equitably because they can attach conditions to grant funding.
Principal investigators make the main decisions about how to conduct research and are best placed to push for equitable research partnerships in practice.
Publishers have the most influence because they can refuse to publish research that is not undertaken equitably.
Research ethics committees have a lot of power as they can request changes to the research protocol.
A collaboration of all stakeholders is required, individual groups cannot make a difference.

components.prompt: Reflective review of the potential applicability of the TRUST code articles to wider settings
components.content:
Which articles of the TRUST code do you think could be relevant beyond research in resource-limited settings?
Tick all articles that you think could be applied to different types of settings then click submit to see how others have voted and to access our feedback.
There are no right or wrong answers, this exercise will help you to reflect on your commitment to inclusive research. Your answers are anonymous.

options.title: ARTICLE 1
options.description: Local relevance of research is essential and should be determined in collaboration with local partners. Research that is not relevant in the location where it is undertaken imposes burdens without benefits.

options.title: ARTICLE 2
options.description: Local communities and research participants should be included throughout the research process, wherever possible, from planning through to post-study feedback and evaluation, to ensure that their perspectives are fairly represented. This approach represents Good Participatory Practice.

options.title: ARTICLE 3
options.description: Feedback about the findings of the research must be given to local communities and research participants. It should be provided in a way that is meaningful, appropriate and readily comprehended.

options.title: ARTICLE 4
options.description: Local researchers should be included, wherever possible, throughout the research process, including in study design, study implementation, data ownership, intellectual property and authorship of publications.

options.title: ARTICLE 5
options.description: Access by researchers to any biological or agricultural resources, human biological materials, traditional knowledge, cultural artefacts or non-renewable resources such as minerals should be subject to the free and prior informed consent of the owners or custodians. Formal agreements should govern the transfer of any material or knowledge to researchers, on terms that are co-developed with resource custodians or knowledge holders.

options.title: ARTICLE 6
options.description: Any research that uses biological materials and associated information such as traditional knowledge or genetic sequence data should clarify to participants the potential monetary and non-monetary benefits that might arise. A culturally appropriate plan to share benefits should be agreed to by all relevant stakeholders, and reviewed regularly as the research evolves. Researchers from high-income settings need to be aware of the power and resource differentials in benefit-sharing discussions, with sustained efforts to bring lower-capacity parties into the dialogue.

options.title: ARTICLE 7
options.description: It is essential to compensate local research support systems, for instance translators, interpreters or local coordinators, fairly for their contribution to research projects.

options.title: ARTICLE 8
options.description: Potential cultural sensitivities should be explored in advance of research with local communities, research participants and local researchers to avoid violating customary practices. Research is a voluntary exercise for research participants. It is not a mission-driven exercise to impose different ethical values. If researchers from high-income settings cannot agree on a way of undertaking the research that is acceptable to local stakeholders, it should not take place.

options.title: ARTICLE 9
options.description: Community assent should be obtained through recognized local structures, if required locally. While individual consent must not be compromised, assent from the community may be an ethical prerequisite and a sign of respect for the entire community. It is the responsibility of the researcher to find out local requirements.

options.title: ARTICLE 10
options.description: Local ethics review should be sought wherever possible. It is of vital importance that research projects are approved by a research ethics committee in the host country, wherever this exists, even if ethics approval has already been obtained in the high-income setting.

options.title: ARTICLE 11
options.description: Researchers from high-income settings should show respect to host country research ethics committees.

options.title: ARTICLE 12
options.description: Informed consent procedures should be tailored to local requirements to achieve genuine understanding and well-founded decision-making.

options.title: ARTICLE 13
options.description: A clear procedure for feedback, complaints or allegations of misconduct must be offered that gives genuine and appropriate access to all research participants and local partners to express any concerns they may have with the research process. This procedure must be agreed with local partners at the outset of the research.

options.title: ARTICLE 14
options.description: Research that would be severely restricted or prohibited in a high-income setting should not be carried out in a lower-income setting. Exceptions might be permissible in the context of specific local conditions (e.g. diseases not prevalent in high-income countries). If and when such exceptions are dealt with, the internationally acknowledged compliance commandment “comply or explain” must be used, i.e. exceptions agreed upon by the local stakeholders and researchers must be explicitly and transparently justified and made easily accessible to interested parties.

options.title: ARTICLE 15
options.description: Where research involvement could lead to stigmatization (e.g. research on sexually transmitted diseases), incrimination (e.g. sex work), discrimination or indeterminate personal risk (e.g. research on political beliefs), special measures to ensure the safety and wellbeing of research participants need to be agreed with local partners.

options.title: ARTICLE 16
options.description: Ahead of the research it should be determined whether local resources will be depleted to provide staff or other resources for the new project (e.g. nurses or laboratory staff). If so, the implications should be discussed in detail with local communities, partners and authorities and monitored during the study.

options.title: ARTICLE 17
options.description: In situations where animal welfare regulations are inadequate or non-existent in the local setting compared with the country of origin of the researcher, animal experimentation should always be undertaken in line with the higher standards of protection for animals.

options.title: ARTICLE 18
options.description: In situations where environmental protection and biorisk-related regulations are inadequate or non-existent in the local setting compared with the country of origin of the researcher, research should always be undertaken in line with the higher standards of environmental protection.

options.title: ARTICLE 19
options.description: Where research may involve health, safety or security risks for researchers or expose researchers to conflicts of conscience, tailored risk management plans should be agreed in advance of the research between the research team, local partners and employers.

options.title: ARTICLE 20
options.description: A clear understanding should be reached among collaborators with regard to their roles, responsibilities and conduct throughout the research cycle, from study design through to study implementation, review and dissemination. Capacity-building plans for local researchers should be part of these discussions.

options.title: ARTICLE 21
options.description: Lower educational standards, illiteracy or language barriers can never be an excuse for hiding information or providing it incompletely. Information must always be presented honestly and as clearly as possible. Plain language and a non-patronising style in the appropriate local languages should be adopted in communication with research participants who may have difficulties comprehending the research process and requirements.

options.title: ARTICLE 22
options.description: Corruption and bribery of any kind cannot be accepted or supported by researchers from any countries.

options.title: ARTICLE 23
options.description: Lower local data protection standards or compliance procedures can never be an excuse to tolerate the potential for privacy breaches. Special attention must be paid to research participants who are at risk of stigmatization, discrimination or incrimination through the research participation.

components.feedback: Thank you for taking part in this exercise. We hope that you found it useful to reflect on the application of the TRUST code articles in different research settings. Were you surprised by the number of articles that you ticked? Inclusive research has benefits in all research settings, and many articles of the TRUST Code recommend conduct which would also be suitable in high income countries, especially when people in vulnerable situations are involved.

components.title: Many ethics guidance documents are written in a very technical manner and are very long, sometimes over 100 pages. What are the advantages and disadvantages of very short, jargon-free codes, like the TRUST Code?
components.subtitle: Please decide if the following items are advantages or disadvantages, then drag and drop them into the correct category.
components.description:
It might require a short waiting time before you can drag the next item.
If you wish to change your choices, you can easily do this by clicking on the 'undo' icon that appears on each item when selected.
components.feedback: As you might have guessed, we are big fans of the practicality of short, jargon-free codes and have seen the advantages of this over the years since the TRUST code was launched in 2018 at the European Parliament.

bucket_items.label: Understanding short, jargon-free codes does not require any specialised knowledge.
The guidance can be used directly by those who are potentially exploited, for instance, communities in lower income settings.
The guidance is flexible enough to realise the essence of an article through local solutions.
Users of the guidance do not need a lot of available time to read and understand the code.
The guidance does not offer solutions for every conceivable situation.
The need to synthesize a lot of material makes short codes very time-consuming to produce.
Some people believe in long codes.
